last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>81194017
Have you really done a comparison? After years of fighting with configuration management systems that seemed bound and determined to go backwards from where we were in 2007 I gave up and just wrote my own system from scratch using Python. It isn't pretty and I made some mistakes in the design but it's still way better to work with than puppet, ansible, or chef.

It's not general-purpose. It's specifically tailored to solve the problems I have. I've encountered a few idempotency issues but nothing serious (in fact I still haven't bothered to fix the biggest one I found since it's such a trivial thing). Plus I can easily integrate some features like having every configuration update check the important parts into a local git repo. So if I want to see the history of changes on any given server I can just browse to /etc/<myshit>/config and use standard git commands to browse the history and can even check in temporary manual modifications for troubleshooting. It's much nicer than whatever puppet's custom lock-in feature alternative is. Which incidentally caused problems as it was bucketing "ssh_known_hosts" every single time it changed, for a huge cluster where nodes were constantly being added and removed. And it wasn't doing it in any kind of compressed or diff-based way there were just fucking thousands of useless copies of this file stored on the disks of every single node in the cluster. Nobody told puppet to do this on purpose. It happened automatically when someone installed some standard puppet module.

Anyway back to the point, is that the total amount of "reinventing the wheel badly" that I did for my project amounts to about 500 lines of code (that includes the git wrappers). I won't deny it's a badly reinvented wheel but it hasn't caused problems. The rest is all custom domain-specific problem-solving that would have been hell to develop in .pp.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>81195682
Bootstrap starts you off easy by giving you present components that you can tweak globally with Sass variables, but you still need to write your own CSS if you want to override some of those (which can be tricky). Tailwind is the best of both speed to write and flexibillity, especially when it comes to responsivee sizes and states like hover etc. Also has bonus features like light/dark mode switching

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>81194981
You learn that kind of stuff when you have a bit more experience. No company is gonna let a newbie touch something as important as their system infrastructure.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>81195682
It gives you a lot of freedom while setting some limits that ensure your designs look decent.
I never liked Bootstrap because you had to either learn strict HTML structures or always have the docs at hand to copy paste and every website ended up looking the same. That does not happen with Tailwind.
You can extend or tweak pretty much everything.
There's also a lot of components libraries if you wanna take the fast route, putting it on pair with BS.
Creating responsive websites is a cakewalk again (and again, you can modify it to work either mobile or desktop first).

The amount of options it offers is enormous, to the point of seen CSS properties I've never used.
One complaint people had is that if you wanted to avoid shipping extra CSS files you could find yourself writing inline styles for properties that weren't defined by default or edge cases that you didn't account in your custom config.
Now with the JIT compiler you can do shit like
m-[666px]

and it would create that CSS rule on the fly.
You also don't have to build the whole framework to start working, which is quite heavy and can slow down the browser.

I really encourage you to give it a go. At first I was like "well that's just writing inline styles", but it really grew on my fast. It also has one of the best docs I've ever seen.

FAQ:
How do I get started?

>What are the available graphics drivers?
amdgpu(4): AMD Radeon GPUs
intel(4): Intel integrated graphics chipsets
radeon(4): ATI/AMD Radeon video driver
efifb(4): EFI frame buffer
vesa(4): Generic VESA video driver

>What are the available wireless drivers?
https://man.openbsd.org/?query=wireless&apropos=1

https://sivers.org/openbsd

>Should I use -release or -current?
If you're using it in your home machine, then -current is most likely what you're looking for since it contains updated packages.

>How do I follow -current?
https://www.openbsd.org/faq/current.html

>How do I upgrade -current to the latest snapshot?
Just run sysupgrade(8) as root.

OpenBSD man pages: https://man.openbsd.org/

last_replies.com: Any *nix system you use is almost guaranteed to have some version of vi available. Most ship with others but if you ever get dropped onto some stripped-down busybox OS, chances are vi might be your only option for editing files outside of sed/awk.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>81194781
chances are that it's more hassle than it's worth to make it your main editor. However, learning how to use it on a basic level (how to copy/paste, delete lines, jump to start/end/specific line etc) has been of immense use to me because it's better to use for small edits to config files than nano, and vi keybindings are available in a lot of editors (sublime and vs have them)

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: If you get good with it you can move around and edit a text file quickly and since it has modes (ie normal, insert, visual, command) you're not constantly pressing keychords (eg ctrl+alt+whatever) which is more comfortable for the fingers.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>81195423
>The network stack is hardware in the NIC. Well, NICs are really computers running custom firmwares nowadays so who knows what they are really doing. And it doesn't even have to be the special Intel NIC due to NC-SI/MCTP/iforgotthethirdone'sacronym.

For the Intel NICs 8XXXX-LM/I2XX-LM isn't the network stack in the LAN/ME region of the BIOS, which means the ME region matters? This is why you typically cannot just take someone else's BIOS and flash them onto your motherboard even if it is the same model because you will flash a wrong MAC address into your motherboard. Intel NICs usually have very little memory(non-rewritable) for setting of bits, and if you want more features you need an external SPI chip for Option ROM (look at I210 vs I211 for example, and how using I210 without SPI restricts its functionalities).

Not sure how PXE is relevant; they just load stuff off of the option ROM anyway and do not integrate drivers itself.

The sizes doesn't really matter; the size difference matters as the network stack could be there.

And you mean it can be via other NICs or it can be via other connection methods like WiFi/LTE?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>81195904
>For the Intel NICs 8XXXX-LM/I2XX-LM isn't the network stack in the LAN/ME region of the BIOS, which means the ME region matters?
As in >>81195423
>me_cleaner docs suggest that 'The network stack (partition NFTP)' is always present
>This is why you typically cannot just take someone else's BIOS and flash them onto your motherboard even if it is the same model because you will flash a wrong MAC address into your motherboard.
This issue can be sidestepped since Intel has a tool for reflashing the MAC, for AIC it's bootutil and for LOM there's a separate one which is not directly downloadable. It is usually part of the UEFI capsule update so can be extracted.
>Not sure how PXE is relevant; they just load stuff off of the option ROM anyway and do not integrate drivers itself.
UEFI PXE is not Legacy PXE. The former contains a full TCP/IP with HTTP(S) boot capability.
>And you mean it can be via other NICs or it can be via other connection methods like WiFi/LTE?
Both, for example there's a specific Realtek Ethernet NIC model that allows AMT functions, but it's not used much due to Intel preferring their own. vPro for laptops can function with WiFi/LTE, but obviously on compatible adapters.

>Troubleshooting
If there seems to be a bug (or complicated issue), anons may ask you to compose an MWE (minimum working example).
To create an MWE, try the following:
1) start emacs with "emacs -q". This disables your init.
2) try to reproduce your issue with as few settings changed and packages (manually) loaded as possible.
These steps ensure that other anons can replicate your problem if it's something more involved. Sometimes you even find the cause yourself this way, too!

This is a valid criticism. In the Lisp community it's a well-known problem, known as the "Lisp curse".

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>81194201
>Do lists have to be able to run on their own?

No, you can definitely have lists of values.
But if you evaluate a list, it's going to apply the first item as a procedure.

To declare a list that is not evaluated, you can quote it:

> (quote (1 2 3))
(1 2 3)


There is a shorter notation to quote:

> '(1 2 3)
(1 2 3)


So I can have something like this:

(define numbers '(1 83 192))

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>81194525
>So are there instances where it's useful to only read a list with a function inside it instead of evaluating it?

It allows to write macros.
For example, a predefined macro (in Scheme) is delay, which allows to implement lazy evaluation.

(define x (delay (fact 1000)))


Here, you would think that, based on what we just described, it would run "fact 1000", because it's not quoted, right? Well, there's one exception. Or, rather, it's not an exception, but in the example above it's a bit hidden from the programmer. In fact delay will not run the code immediately, but keep it for later. So its input is not the result from the factorial of 1000, but indeed the list (fact 1000).

When I want the value later, I can do:

(force x)

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>81188194
LLVM was actually created as a GCC backend, and that is how it was used for a VERY long time.

When GCC went GPLv3, Apple who has always been hating the GPL, decided to create their own frontend for LLVM, called Clang, which was proprietary for a long time, until they realised it was developing too slow, and open sourced it.

And that is how we arrived at Clang/LLVM, which of course is the preferred choice for corporations as they can choose if they want to contribute back, rather than having to do so.
